docs.abstract: Black Pound Day was created to find a sustainable way to support Black-owned businesses after the Black Lives Matter street protests faded.
docs.snippet: Black Pound Day was created to find a sustainable way to support Black-owned businesses after the Black Lives Matter street protests faded.
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON — For Aimée Felone, whose children’s bookstore in London stocks tales with ethnically diverse characters, the Black Lives Matter protests last summer were, in a word, overwhelming.

headline.main: After the Pandemic and Protests, a British Rapper Spotlights Black Businesses

docs.abstract: In an unusual move, Detective Vincent Cheung is suing a man who hurled racist insults at him. The lawsuit raises thorny questions about free speech.
docs.snippet: In an unusual move, Detective Vincent Cheung is suing a man who hurled racist insults at him. The lawsuit raises thorny questions about free speech.
docs.lead_paragraph: When demonstrations against racism and brutality in policing filled New York’s streets last summer, the police confronted protesters with tactics so aggressive and at times violent that a remorseful Mayor Bill de Blasio later issued a public apology.

headline.main: Why This N.Y.P.D. Detective Is Suing a Protester
headline.print_headline: New York City Detective Is Suing a Demonstrator For Using Racist Insults

docs.abstract: The company said it planned to limit posts that contain misinformation and hate speech related to the trial to keep them from spilling over into real-world harm.
docs.snippet: The company said it planned to limit posts that contain misinformation and hate speech related to the trial to keep them from spilling over into real-world harm.
docs.lead_paragraph: Facebook on Monday said it planned to limit posts that contain misinformation and hate speech related to the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged with the murder of George Floyd, to keep them from spilling over into real-world harm.

headline.main: Facebook, preparing for Chauvin verdict, to limit posts that might incite violence.

docs.abstract: From social justice themes to stories about grief and reckoning with the past, this year’s nominated shorts get serious.
docs.snippet: From social justice themes to stories about grief and reckoning with the past, this year’s nominated shorts get serious.
docs.lead_paragraph: This year, the Oscar-nominated short films are being presented in three programs: live action, animation and documentary. Each program is reviewed below by a separate critic.

headline.main: ‘The 2021 Oscar Nominated Short Films’ Review: Major Issues in Brief

byline.original: By Jeannette Catsoulis, Maya Phillips and Ben Kenigsberg

docs.abstract: Assembled in a mere four months, pivoting off an important national event, the Speed Museum offers a new, relevant model for aging institutions.
docs.snippet: Assembled in a mere four months, pivoting off an important national event, the Speed Museum offers a new, relevant model for aging institutions.
docs.lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — People talk a lot about getting back to pre-Covid normal. But our traditional art museums can forget about that. After a year of intense racial justice reckoning, a paralyzing pandemic and crippling economic shortfalls, aging hidebound institutions are scrambling just to stay afloat. And the only way for them to do so is to change. Strategies for forward motion are needed. One is in play here at the Speed Art Museum, in the form of a quietly passionate show called “Promise, Witness, Remembrance,” which might, with profit, be studied by other institutions in survivalist mode.

headline.main: Breonna Taylor Show Puts Art Museums on a Faster Track

docs.abstract: What happened to George Floyd is the latest in a long line of incidents of police violence captured on camera. We watched the Chauvin trial with the families of Rodney King, Oscar Grant and Stephon Clark to see this moment in history through their eyes.
docs.snippet: What happened to George Floyd is the latest in a long line of incidents of police violence captured on camera. We watched the Chauvin trial with the families of Rodney King, Oscar Grant and Stephon Clark to see this moment in history through their...
docs.lead_paragraph: “I don’t watch the footage of my dad’s incident because it is torture,” said Lora Dene King, whose father, Rodney G. King, was brutally beaten by the police in Los Angeles. “Here it is 30 years later and nothing has changed.”

headline.main: Watching the Derek Chauvin Trial With Families Affected by Police Violence
headline.print_headline: Watching the Trial and Reliving Their Own Nightmare

byline.original: By Nilo Tabrizy and Débora Souza Silva
